messages.content: Don't make assumptions about what values to plug into functions. Ask for clarification if a user request is ambiguous.

Sure—by “later,” do you want to see just the reminders you still have scheduled for the rest of today, for the next few days, or all upcoming reminders in general? Let me know the timeframe you’re interested in and I’ll pull up the relevant items.

Got it—so you’d like to see everything still scheduled between now and midnight tonight. What time is it currently on your device? That lets me pull any reminder whose alert time falls after “right now” but before the end of today.
I’m actually not sure what time it is right now.

No problem—I don’t have direct access to your device’s clock, so I need a reference point to know which reminders are still “upcoming.” If you’d like, I can simply show every reminder scheduled for any time today (from 12:00 a.m. through 11:59 p.m.). That way you’ll see everything and can ignore anything that’s already happened.

Would you like me to pull up all reminders for today?
Sure thing—just to get the date range right, could you tell me today’s date (for example, “June 25 2025”)? Once I know the date, I can pull every reminder whose alert time falls on that day.
I’m not sure of today’s date either.

messages.name: search_reminder
messages.content: ValueError: No search criteria are given. At least one search criteria should be provided among ('reminder_id', 'content', 'creation_timestamp', 'creation_timestamp', 'reminder_timestamp', 'reminder_timestamp', 'latitude', 'longitude')

I’m afraid I don’t have a way to read the date or time from your device automatically, so I still need at least a rough idea of “today” to pull the correct reminders. If you can quickly glance at your phone or computer and tell me the current date (month, day, and year) I’ll filter everything for that day; otherwise, I can show you all reminders you have—past and future—and you can manually ignore anything not relevant.

Which would you prefer?
